qas.question: What does ἰδεῖν mean in English?
By what year was "idealism" a word in English?
Whose worldview contrasts with that of idealists in the ordinary sense of the word?
When did the Greek word idein mean to see?
What does the English word idein mean?
Idealists see the world the same way as what other philosophers?

plausible_answers.text: affirms imagination and attempts to realize a mental conception of beauty

qas.question: How do pragmatists view the arts?

context: Idealism is a term with several related meanings. It comes via idea from the <a3_0>Greek<a3_0/> idein (ἰδεῖν), meaning "<a0_0><b6_0>to see<b6_0/><a0_0/>". The term entered the English language by <a1_0><b4_0>1743<b4_0/><a1_0/>. In ordinary use, as when speaking of <b5_0>Woodrow Wilson<b5_0/>'s political idealism, it generally suggests the priority of ideals, principles, values, and goals over concrete realities. Idealists are understood to represent the world as it might or should be, unlike <a2_0><b7_0>pragmatists<b7_0/><a2_0/>, who focus on the world as it presently is. In the arts, similarly, idealism <b8_0>affirms imagination and attempts to realize a mental conception of beauty<b8_0/>, a standard of perfection, juxtaposed to aesthetic naturalism and realism.
